articles.title: George E. Smith obituary: co-inventor of the charge coupled device, which ushered in an era of digital images
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 07 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02515-9Smith’s invention enabled the precise capture of light in electronic form, and has transformed science, medicine and daily life.
articles.content:
Credit: Olivier Morin/AFP via Getty

George E. Smith’s collaboration with Willard Boyle at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, New Jersey, led to the invention of the charge coupled device (CCD) in October 1969. Over an hour’s brainstorming session, in which they set out to design a memory device, the two engineers came up with an idea about how to move electrons between capacitors in a semiconductor. Owing to the dynamic and research-focused nature of Bell Labs, the idea was implemented in silicon just a week after it was conceived (W. S. Boyle and G. E. Smith Bell Syst. Tech. J. 49, 587–593; 1970), and proved ideally suited to capturing images. Boyle and Smith shared half of the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physics “for the invention of an imaging semiconductor circuit — the CCD sensor”.

The invention was subsequently part of the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and other space missions, transforming their ability to photograph astronomical objects, and was incorporated into many other applications including television cameras, medical radiography and digital consumer products. CCDs detect light using the photoelectric effect: the emission of electrons when light hits a material. They are sensitive to wavelengths between 300 and 1,000 nanometres. Absorbed photons liberate electrons, so they drift under the influence of whatever electric fields are present.

The challenge for CCD designers is to manipulate such fields to ensure that these photoelectrons are collected efficiently and stored without loss during exposure. Once the shutter closes and the read-out begins, this charge then needs to be converted to a voltage signal and digitized with as little extra noise as possible. The genius of the CCD design is that the same structures that the device uses to collect light also transfer the photo-generated charge to a measurement amplifier at the edge of the detector once the exposure has finished.

Will AI jeopardize science photography? There’s still time to create an ethical code of conduct

Smith was born in White Plains, New York, in 1930. After four years in the US Navy, he studied physics at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia before gaining his PhD at the University of Chicago, Illinois, in 1959. He then moved to Bell Labs, and worked under Boyle, studying the electronic properties of semi-metals and low-temperature electronic technologies, before Boyle made him head of the new device concepts group.

At the time they invented CCDs, exploiting the earlier Bell Labs invention of metal–oxide–semiconductor capacitors, Smith was working on a videophone based on a silicon-diode-array camera tube. It was never developed because of the difficulties of manufacturing chips with one million perfect diodes, but his exploration of digital imaging helped the Bell team to realize the potential of CCDs for that purpose.

articles.personality_title: George E. Smith, co-inventor of the charge coupled device, revolutionized digital imaging
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1969, George E. Smith and Willard Boyle at Bell Labs invented the charge coupled device (CCD), a technology that captures light electronically. Their work came from research aimed at developing new memory devices and quickly turned into a new way to create images.

**What happened** – Over one brainstorming session, Smith and Boyle designed a method to move electrons between capacitors in silicon. Within a week, they built a working version. This invention was later used in the Hubble Space Telescope and many other devices like medical imaging equipment and digital cameras. For this work, they shared half of the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physics.

**Impact** – The CCD changed how images are captured by converting light into electrical signals with high precision. It allowed scientists to take clearer pictures of space, helped doctors see inside the body with better detail, and made digital photography common in everyday life. Its ability to gather and transfer light-generated charges efficiently is key to its success.

**What's next step** – The CCD continues to be important in scientific instruments and imaging technology. Future developments may focus on improving sensitivity and reducing noise, while new technologies might build on or complement CCDs to enhance imaging further.

**One-sentence takeaway** – George E. Smith’s invention of the CCD created a foundational technology that transformed photography, science, and medicine by enabling precise digital capture of light.
articles.personality_title_fr: George E. Smith, co-inventeur du dispositif à transfert de charge, a révolutionné l’imagerie numérique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1969, George E. Smith et Willard Boyle des Bell Labs ont inventé le dispositif à transfert de charge (DTC), une technologie qui capture la lumière électroniquement. Leur travail est né d’une recherche visant à développer de nouveaux dispositifs de mémoire et s’est rapidement transformé en une nouvelle façon de créer des images.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors d’une séance de réflexion d’une heure, Smith et Boyle ont conçu une méthode pour déplacer des électrons entre des condensateurs dans le silicium. En une semaine, ils ont construit un prototype fonctionnel. Cette invention a ensuite été utilisée dans le télescope spatial Hubble et de nombreux autres appareils comme l’imagerie médicale et les appareils photo numériques. Pour ce travail, ils ont partagé la moitié du prix Nobel de physique en 2009.

**Impact** – Le DTC a changé la façon dont les images sont capturées en convertissant la lumière en signaux électriques avec une grande précision. Il a permis aux scientifiques de prendre des photos plus nettes de l’espace, aidé les médecins à mieux voir à l’intérieur du corps, et rendu la photographie numérique courante dans la vie quotidienne. Sa capacité à collecter et transférer efficacement les charges générées par la lumière est la clé de son succès.

**Prochaine étape** – Le DTC reste important dans les instruments scientifiques et la technologie d’imagerie. Les développements futurs pourraient viser à améliorer la sensibilité et réduire le bruit, tandis que de nouvelles technologies pourraient compléter ou dépasser le DTC pour améliorer encore l’imagerie.

**Phrase clé** – L’invention du DTC par George E. Smith a créé une technologie fondamentale qui a transformé la photographie, la science et la médecine en permettant une capture numérique précise de la lumière.
articles.personality_title_es: George E. Smith, co-inventor del dispositivo de carga acoplada, revolucionó la imagen digital
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1969, George E. Smith y Willard Boyle en Bell Labs inventaron el dispositivo de carga acoplada (CCD), una tecnología que captura la luz electrónicamente. Su trabajo surgió de una investigación para desarrollar nuevos dispositivos de memoria y rápidamente se convirtió en una nueva forma de crear imágenes.

**Qué pasó** – Durante una sesión de lluvia de ideas de una hora, Smith y Boyle diseñaron un método para mover electrones entre condensadores en silicio. En una semana, construyeron un prototipo funcional. Esta invención se usó luego en el telescopio espacial Hubble y en muchos otros dispositivos como equipos de imagen médica y cámaras digitales. Por este trabajo, compartieron la mitad del Premio Nobel de Física en 2009.

**Impacto** – El CCD cambió cómo se capturan las imágenes al convertir la luz en señales eléctricas con alta precisión. Permitió a los científicos tomar fotos más claras del espacio, ayudó a los médicos a ver mejor dentro del cuerpo y popularizó la fotografía digital en la vida diaria. Su capacidad para recolectar y transferir eficientemente la carga generada por la luz es clave para su éxito.

**Próximo paso** – El CCD sigue siendo importante en instrumentos científicos y tecnología de imagen. Los desarrollos futuros podrían centrarse en mejorar la sensibilidad y reducir el ruido, mientras que nuevas tecnologías podrían complementar o superar al CCD para mejorar aún más la imagen.

**Frase para llevar** – La invención del CCD por George E. Smith creó una tecnología básica que transformó la fotografía, la ciencia y la medicina al permitir la captura digital precisa de la luz.

articles.title: Six months since it stunned markets, how China's DeepSeek is changing AI
articles.summary: Some six months after DeepSeek shook Silicon Valley, is the Chinese AI chatbot still relevant?
articles.content:
It shocked the market but has China's DeepSeek changed AI?

12 hours ago Share Save Lily Jamali • @lilyjamali North America Technology Correspondent Reporting from San Francisco Share Save

Shutterstock

US President Donald Trump had been in office scarcely a week when a new Chinese artificial intelligence (AI) app called DeepSeek jolted Silicon Valley. Overnight, DeepSeek-R1 shot to the top of the Apple charts as the most downloaded free app in the US. The firm said at the time its new chatbot rivalled ChatGPT. Not only that. They asserted it had cost a mere fraction to develop. Those claims – and the app's sudden surge in popularity – wiped $600bn (£446bn) or 17% off the market value of chip giant Nvidia, marking the largest one-day loss for a single stock in the history of the US stock market. Several other tech stocks with exposure to AI were caught in the downdraft, too. DeepSeek also cast doubt on American AI dominance. Up until then, China had been seen as having fallen behind the US. Now, it seemed as though China had catapulted to the forefront. Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen referred to the arrival of DeepSeek-R1 as "AI's Sputnik moment," a reference to the Soviet satellite that had kicked off the space race between the US and the USSR more than a half century earlier.

Bloomberg via Getty Images Shares of Japanese semiconductor-related companies extended a late January drop after the release of Chinese AI model DeepSeek prompted a selloff in US tech stocks

Still relevant

It has now been six months since DeepSeek stunned the world. Today, China's breakthrough app has largely dropped out of the headlines. It's no longer the hot topic at happy hour here in San Francisco. But DeepSeek hasn't disappeared. DeepSeek challenged certain key assumptions about AI that had been championed by American executives like Sam Altman, CEO of ChatGPT-maker OpenAI. "We were on a path where bigger was considered better," according to Sid Sheth, CEO of AI chip startup d-Matrix. Perhaps maxing out on data centres, servers, chips, and the electricity to run it all wasn't the way forward after all. Despite DeepSeek ostensibly not having access to the most powerful tech available at the time, Sheth told the BBC that it showed that "with smarter engineering, you actually can build a capable model". The surge of interest in DeepSeek took hold over a weekend in late January, before corporate IT personnel could move to stop employees from flocking to it. When organisations caught on the following Monday, many scrambled to ban workers from using the app as worries set in about whether user data was potentially being shared with the People's Republic of China, where DeepSeek is based. But while exact numbers aren't available, plenty of Americans still use DeepSeek today. Certain Silicon Valley start-ups have opted to stick with DeepSeek in lieu of more expensive AI models from US firms in a bid to cut down on costs. One investor told me for cash-strapped firms, funds saved by continuing to use DeepSeek are helping to pay for critical needs such as additional headcount. They are, however, being careful. In online forums, users explain how to run DeepSeek-R1 on their own devices rather than online using DeepSeek's servers in China - a workaround they believe can protect their data from being shared surreptitiously. "It's a good way to use the model without being concerned about what it's exfiltrating" to China, said Christopher Caen, CEO of Mill Pond Research.

US-China rivalry

CFOTO/Future Publishing via Getty Images

DeepSeek's arrival also marked a turning point in the US-China AI rivalry, some experts say. "China was seen as playing catch-up in large language models until this point, with competitive models but always trailing the best western ones," policy analyst Wendy Chang of the Mercator Institute for China Studies told the BBC. A large language model (LLM) is a reasoning system trained to predict the next word in a given sentence or phrase. DeepSeek changed perceptions when it claimed to have achieved a leading model for a fraction of the computational resources and costs common among its American counterparts. OpenAI had spent $5bn (£3.7bn) in 2024 alone. By contrast, DeepSeek researchers said they had developed DeepSeek-R1 – which came out on top of OpenAI's o1 model across multiple benchmarks – for just $5.6m (£4.2m). "DeepSeek revealed the competitiveness of China's AI landscape to the world," Chang said. American AI developers have managed to capitalize on this shift. AI-related deals and other announcements trumpeted by the Trump administration and major American tech companies are often framed as critical to staying ahead of China. Trump's AI czar David Sacks noted the technology would have "profound ramifications for both the economy and national security" when the administration unveiled its AI Action Plan last month. "It's just very important that America continues to be the dominant power in AI," Sacks said. DeepSeek has never managed to quell concerns over the security implications of its Chinese origins. The US government has been assessing the company's links to Beijing, as first reported by Reuters in June. A senior US State Department official told the BBC they understood "DeepSeek has willingly provided, and will likely continue to provide, support to China's military and intelligence operations". DeepSeek did not respond to the BBC's request for comment but the company's privacy policy states that its servers are located in the People's Republic of China. "When you access our services, your Personal Data may be processed and stored in our servers in the People's Republic of China," the policy says. "This may be a direct provision of your Personal Data to us or a transfer that we or a third-party make."

Feature China/Future Publishing via Getty Images

A new approach?
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant technological breakthrough by China's DeepSeek AI, which challenged prevailing assumptions about AI development and demonstrated that smarter engineering can produce competitive AI models at a fraction of the usual cost. This story is inspiring as it showcases innovation, competition driving progress, and the potential for more accessible AI technology, which can positively impact the global tech landscape.
articles.personality_title: China's DeepSeek reshapes AI with smarter, cost-effective technology
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In early 2024, the AI landscape was dominated by large, expensive models mostly developed in the United States, with China seen as trailing behind. American companies invested billions in powerful AI systems, setting expectations that bigger and costlier was better.

**What happened** – In January 2024, a Chinese AI chatbot named DeepSeek-R1 suddenly became the most downloaded free app in the US. Developed for just $5.6 million, it challenged leading US models by delivering strong performance with far fewer resources. Its rise caused major disruptions in tech stocks and shifted perceptions about China's role in AI innovation.

**Impact** – DeepSeek proved that high-quality AI can be built with smarter engineering instead of massive computing power. This challenged the belief that bigger investments always produce better AI. Some US startups now use DeepSeek to reduce costs while maintaining competitive capabilities. This competition also intensified attention on data security and the geopolitical rivalry between the US and China in AI development.

**What's next step** – Companies and governments are watching closely how DeepSeek and similar models evolve. There is ongoing debate about balancing innovation with security concerns, including how AI models handle data. Meanwhile, the AI race is expected to drive more efficient and cost-effective technologies on both sides, pushing the industry toward varied approaches.

**One-sentence takeaway** – DeepSeek’s success shows that smarter, affordable AI can compete globally and is reshaping how we think about building advanced technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: DeepSeek de Chine redéfinit l'IA avec une technologie plus intelligente et économique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Début 2024, le domaine de l'IA était dominé par de grands modèles coûteux principalement développés aux États-Unis, la Chine étant perçue comme en retard. Les entreprises américaines investissaient des milliards dans des systèmes puissants, supposant que plus c’est grand et cher, mieux c’est.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En janvier 2024, un chatbot chinois nommé DeepSeek-R1 est soudainement devenu l'application gratuite la plus téléchargée aux États-Unis. Développé pour seulement 5,6 millions de dollars, il a défié les modèles américains en offrant de bonnes performances avec bien moins de ressources. Cette montée a perturbé les actions technologiques et changé la perception du rôle de la Chine dans l'innovation en IA.

**Impact** – DeepSeek a prouvé qu'une IA de haute qualité peut être créée avec une ingénierie plus intelligente plutôt qu'avec une puissance de calcul massive. Cela a remis en question l'idée que de gros investissements produisent toujours une meilleure IA. Certaines startups américaines utilisent désormais DeepSeek pour réduire les coûts tout en restant compétitives. Cette concurrence a aussi renforcé l'attention sur la sécurité des données et la rivalité géopolitique entre les États-Unis et la Chine.

**Prochaine étape** – Les entreprises et gouvernements suivent de près l'évolution de DeepSeek et des modèles similaires. Le débat continue autour de l'innovation et des préoccupations de sécurité, notamment sur la gestion des données par ces IA. La course à l'IA devrait encourager des technologies plus efficaces et économiques des deux côtés, favorisant des approches variées.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le succès de DeepSeek montre qu’une IA intelligente et abordable peut rivaliser mondialement et change la manière de concevoir la technologie avancée.
articles.personality_title_es: DeepSeek de China transforma la IA con tecnología más inteligente y económica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – A principios de 2024, el campo de la IA estaba dominado por grandes modelos costosos desarrollados principalmente en Estados Unidos, mientras China era vista como rezagada. Las empresas estadounidenses invertían miles de millones para crear sistemas potentes, creyendo que más grande y más caro era mejor.

**Qué pasó** – En enero de 2024, un chatbot chino llamado DeepSeek-R1 se convirtió en la aplicación gratuita más descargada en Estados Unidos. Desarrollado por solo 5.6 millones de dólares, desafió a los modelos estadounidenses ofreciendo un buen rendimiento con muchos menos recursos. Su aparición causó trastornos en las acciones tecnológicas y cambió la percepción del papel de China en la innovación en IA.

**Impacto** – DeepSeek demostró que se puede crear una IA de alta calidad con ingeniería más inteligente en lugar de una gran potencia de cómputo. Esto cuestionó la idea de que grandes inversiones siempre producen mejor IA. Algunas startups estadounidenses usan DeepSeek para reducir costos manteniendo capacidades competitivas. Esta competencia también aumentó la atención sobre la seguridad de datos y la rivalidad geopolítica entre EE. UU. y China en IA.

**Próximo paso** – Empresas y gobiernos observan de cerca cómo evolucionan DeepSeek y modelos similares. Continúa el debate sobre equilibrar innovación y preocupaciones de seguridad, incluyendo cómo los modelos de IA manejan los datos. Se espera que la carrera de IA impulse tecnologías más eficientes y económicas en ambos lados, impulsando enfoques variados.

**Mensaje en una frase** – El éxito de DeepSeek muestra que una IA inteligente y asequible puede competir a nivel global y está cambiando la forma de construir tecnología avanzada.
